p: 16 taxa, such as Rosa canina (with 46 references and 56.8%) and Mentha x piperita (with 17 references and 21.0%) ( Fig. 2 , red color), have been identified as the most frequently cited plants. The reason why these herbs are highly cited may be a reflection of their stronger protective and therapeutic effects against flu; this may be the result of the experience gained in Turkish folk medicine for centuries. We would obviously see this when comparing similar studies between 17 geographically close countries ( Fig. 2, blue color). The emergence of the data presented in Table 2 in a similar manner as in Fig. 2 confirms the superior efficacy of these plants, with 76.7% similarity.
